Drowning in delusion, they create evil like worms in a latrine enjoying the latrine, not realizing or knowing that they accumulate heavy burdens beyond measure, from the four grave offenses and five heinous crimes up to the most heinous offenders, with birth and death vast and boundless.

It says, Now wishing to repent, one should go against this flow of offenses and use ten kinds of thoughts to overturn and remove evil dharmas.
First, deeply believing in cause and effect, firmly and clearly.

Although the seeds of karma may last for a long time, they will never perish, and in the end one will not create karma while others experience the results. Second, feeling ashamed and blaming oneself, despising the most sinful person without shame or embarrassment, practicing the ways of animals and abandoning the foremost adornment of purity.
Alas! Without a hook, one creates these grave offenses. The heavens see my hidden sins, and therefore I am ashamed of the heavens;

This is the opposite of the mind of shamelessness and lack of conscience.

Third, fearing the evil destinies, human life is impermanent, and in one breath one is gone for a thousand years. The long road of the netherworld has no provisions, and the vast ocean of suffering has no place to rely on.

It is like a fox that loses its ears, tail, and teeth, pretending to sleep in the hope of escaping. Suddenly hearing that its head will be cut off, its heart is greatly shocked.
Even though one encounters birth, old age, and sickness, one still does not consider death urgent. How can one not be afraid?

This reverses the mind that is not afraid of the evil realms.
Fourth, one should confess without concealing faults. Thieves, poisons, and evil grasses must be urgently removed. When the roots are exposed, the branches wither, and the source dries up.

This reverses the mind that constantly thinks of evil things.

Sixth, giving rise to the bodhi mind means that in the past one's own peace and safety harmed all sentient beings everywhere, but now one widely gives rise to the mind of benefiting others and extends to the realm of space to benefit others.
This reverses the mind that gives rise to evil everywhere.

Seventh, cultivating merit to make up for faults means that in the past one committed offenses with the three karmas day and night without counting, but now one diligently rectifies the good with body, speech, and mind without resting. Without moving mountains and filling rivers, how can one make up for it?
This reverses the mind that indulges the three karmas.

Eighth, guarding and protecting the true Dharma means that in the past one extinguished one's own goodness and also extinguished the goodness of others, neither rejoicing in oneself nor rejoicing in others. Now one guards and protects all goodness, skillfully increasing and expanding it without allowing it to be cut off.
